data.title: How an English coach and Swan Lake sparked Ostersunds’ transformation
data.meta_description: In a stadium 200 miles south of the Arctic Circle, snow swirls and settles on the bleachers. It is -20C and everything is blanketed white, leaving the rainbow f
data.text:
In a stadium 200 miles south of the Arctic Circle, snow swirls and settles on the bleachers. It is -20C and everything is blanketed white, leaving the rainbow flag outside the ground a solitary scrap of colour in this monochrome landscape. Down below, two men in parkas busy themselves with shovels, trying to clear the snow from the stands. It seems like a hopeless task. But if the story of Ostersunds teaches anything, it is that even if something seems impossible, even when the forces of nature are arrayed against you, you have to be bold enough to try.

In a room overlooking the pitch, Daniel Kindberg, a suited former Swedish army colonel, reminisces. “We’d just been relegated to the fourth tier,” he says of
